words.def: Absolute differential calculus: the original name for tensor calculus developed around 1890.
words.name: Absolute differential calculus

words.def: Absolute geometry: an extension of ordered geometry that is sometimes referred to as neutral geometry because its axiom system is neutral to the parallel postulate.
words.name: Absolute geometry

words.def: Abstract algebra: the study of algebraic structures and their properties. Originally it was known as modern algebra.
words.name: Abstract algebra

words.def: Abstract analytic number theory: a branch mathematics that take ideas from classical analytic number theory and applies them to various other areas of mathematics.
words.name: Abstract analytic number theory

words.def: Abstract differential geometry: a form of differential geometry without the notion of smoothness from calculus. Instead it is built using sheaf theory and sheaf cohomology.
words.name: Abstract differential geometry

words.def: Abstract harmonic analysis: a modern branch of harmonic analysis that extends upon the generalized Fourier transforms that can be defined on locally compact groups.
words.name: Abstract harmonic analysis

words.def: Additive combinatorics: the part of arithmetic combinatorics devoted to the operations of addition and subtraction.
words.name: Additive combinatorics

words.def: Additive number theory: a part of number theory that studies subsets of integers and their behaviour under addition.
words.name: Additive number theory

words.def: Affine geometry: a branch of geometry that is centered on the study of geometric properties that remain unchanged by affine transformations. It can be described as a generalization of Euclidean geometry.
words.name: Affine geometry

words.def: Affine geometry of curves: the study of curves in affine space.
words.name: Affine geometry of curves

words.def: Affine differential geometry: a type of differential geometry dedicated to differential invariants under volume-preserving affine transformations.
words.name: Affine differential geometry

words.def: Ahlfors theory: a part of complex analysis being the geometric counterpart of Nevanlinna theory. It was invented by Lars Ahlfors
words.name: Ahlfors theory

words.def: Algebra: a major part of pure mathematics centered on operations and relations. Beginning with elementary algebra, it introduces the concept of variables and how these can be manipulated towards problem solving; known as equation solving. Generalizations of operations and relations defined on sets have led to the idea of an algebraic structure which are studied in abstract algebra. Other branches of algebra include universal algebra, linear algebra and multilinear algebra.
words.name: Algebra

words.def: Algebraic analysis: motivated by systems of linear partial differential equations, it is a branch of algebraic geometry and algebraic topology that uses methods from sheaf theory and complex analysis, to study the properties and generalizations of functions. It was started by Mikio Sato.
words.name: Algebraic analysis

words.def: Algebraic combinatorics: an area that employs methods of abstract algebra to problems of combinatorics. It also refers to the application of methods from combinatorics to problems in abstract algebra.
words.name: Algebraic combinatorics

words.def: Algebraic computation: see symbolic computation.
words.name: Algebraic computation

words.def: Algebraic geometry: a branch that combines techniques from abstract algebra with the language and problems of geometry. Fundamentally, it studies algebraic varieties.
words.name: Algebraic geometry

words.def: Algebraic graph theory: a branch of graph theory in which methods are taken from algebra and employed to problems about graphs. The methods are commonly taken from group theory and linear algebra.
words.name: Algebraic graph theory

words.def: Algebraic K-theory: an important part of homological algebra concerned with defining and applying a certain sequence of functors from rings to abelian groups.
words.name: Algebraic K-theory

words.def: Algebraic number theory: a part of algebraic geometry devoted to the study of the points of the algebraic varieties whose coordinates belong to an algebraic number field. It is a major branch of number theory and is also said to study algebraic structures related to algebraic integers.
words.name: Algebraic number theory

words.def: Algebraic statistics: the use of algebra to advance statistics, although the term is sometimes restricted to label the use of algebraic geometry and commutative algebra in statistics.
words.name: Algebraic statistics

words.def: Algebraic topology: a branch that uses tools from abstract algebra for topology to study topological spaces.
words.name: Algebraic topology

words.def: Algorithmic number theory: also known as computational number theory, it is the study of algorithms for performing number theoretic computations.
words.name: Algorithmic number theory

words.def: Anabelian geometry: an area of study based on the theory proposed by Alexander Grothendieck in the 1980s that describes the way a geometric object of an algebraic variety (such as an algebraic fundamental group) can be mapped into another object, without it being an abelian group.
words.name: Anabelian geometry

words.def: Analysis: a rigorous branch of pure mathematics that had its beginnings in the formulation of infinitesimal calculus. (Then it was known as infinitesimal analysis.) The classical forms of analysis are real analysis and its extension complex analysis, whilst more modern forms are those such as functional analysis.
words.name: Analysis

words.def: Analytic combinatorics: part of enumerative combinatorics where methods of complex analysis are applied to generating functions.
words.name: Analytic combinatorics

words.def: Analytic geometry: usually this refer to the study of geometry using a coordinate system (also known as Cartesian geometry). Alternatively it can refer to the geometry of analytic varieties. In this respect it is essentially equivalent to real and complex algebraic geometry.
words.name: Analytic geometry

words.def: Analytic number theory: part of number theory using methods of analysis (as opposed to algebraic number theory)
words.name: Analytic number theory

words.def: Applied mathematics: a combination of various parts of mathematics that concern a variety of mathematical methods that can be applied to practical and theoretical problems. Typically the methods used are for science, engineering, finance, economics and logistics.
words.name: Applied mathematics

words.def: Approximation theory: part of analysis that studies how well functions can be approximated by simpler ones (such as polynomials or trigonometric polynomials)
words.name: Approximation theory

words.def: Arakelov geometry: also known as Arakelov theory
words.name: Arakelov geometry

words.def: Arakelov theory: an approach to Diophantine geometry used to study Diophantine equations in higher dimensions (using techniques from algebraic geometry). It is named after Suren Arakelov.
words.name: Arakelov theory

words.def: Arithmetic: to most people this refers to the branch known as elementary arithmetic dedicated to the usage of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. However arithmetic also includes higher arithmetic referring to advanced results from number theory.
words.name: Arithmetic

words.def: Arithmetic algebraic geometry: see arithmetic geometry
words.name: Arithmetic algebraic geometry

words.def: Arithmetic combinatorics: the study of the estimates from combinatorics that are associated with arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication and division.
words.name: Arithmetic combinatorics

words.def: Arithmetic geometry: the study of schemes of finite type over the spectrum of the ring of integers
words.name: Arithmetic geometry

words.def: Arithmetic topology: a combination of algebraic number theory and topology studying analogies between prime ideals and knots
words.name: Arithmetic topology

words.def: Arithmetical algebraic geometry: an alternative name for arithmetic algebraic geometry
words.name: Arithmetical algebraic geometry

words.def: Asymptotic theory: the study of asymptotic expansions
words.name: Asymptotic theory

words.def: Auslander–Reiten theory: the study of the representation theory of Artinian rings
words.name: Auslander–Reiten theory

words.def: Axiomatic geometry: see synthetic geometry.
words.name: Axiomatic geometry

words.def: Axiomatic set theory: the study of systems of axioms in a context relevant to set theory and mathematical logic.
words.name: Axiomatic set theory

words.def: Bifurcation theory: the study of changes in the qualitative or topological structure of a given family. It is a part of dynamical systems theory
words.name: Bifurcation theory

words.def: Birational geometry: a part of algebraic geometry that deals with the geometry (of an algebraic variety) that is dependent only on its function field.
words.name: Birational geometry

words.def: Bolyai-Lobachevskian geometry: see hyperbolic geometry.
words.name: Bolyai-Lobachevskian geometry

words.def: Cartesian geometry: see analytic geometry
words.name: Cartesian geometry

words.def: Calculus: a branch usually associated with limits, functions, derivatives, integrals and infinite series. It forms the basis of classical analysis, and historically was called the calculus of infinitesimals or infinitesimal calculus. Now it can refer to a system of calculation guided by symbolic manipulation.
words.name: Calculus

words.def: Calculus of infinitesimals: also known as infinitesimal calculus. It is a branch of calculus built upon the concepts of infinitesimals.
words.name: Calculus of infinitesimals

words.def: Calculus of moving surfaces: an extension of the theory of tensor calculus to include deforming manifolds.
words.name: Calculus of moving surfaces

words.def: Calculus of variations: the field dedicated to maximizing or minimizing functionals. It used to be called functional calculus.
words.name: Calculus of variations

words.def: Catastrophe theory: a branch of bifurcation theory from dynamical systems theory, and also a special case of the more general singularity theory from geometry. It analyses the germs of the catastrophe geometries.
words.name: Catastrophe theory

words.def: Categorical logic: a branch of category theory adjacent to the mathematical logic. It is based on type theory for intuitionistic logics.
words.name: Categorical logic

words.def: Category theory: the study of the properties of particular mathematical concepts by formalising them as collections of objects and arrows.
words.name: Category theory

words.def: Chaos theory: the study of the behaviour of dynamical systems that are highly sensitive to their initial conditions.
words.name: Chaos theory

words.def: Character theory: a branch of group theory that studies the characters of group representations or modular representations.
words.name: Character theory

words.def: Class field theory: a branch of algebraic number theory that studies abelian extensions of number fields.
words.name: Class field theory

words.def: Classical differential geometry: also known as Euclidean differential geometry. see Euclidean differential geometry.
words.name: Classical differential geometry

words.def: Classical analysis: usually refers to the more traditional topics of analysis such as real analysis and complex analysis. It includes any work that does not use techniques from functional analysis and is sometimes called hard analysis. However it may also refer to mathematical analysis done according to the principles of classical mathematics.
words.name: Classical analysis

words.def: Classical Euclidean geometry: see Euclidean geometry
words.name: Classical Euclidean geometry

words.def: Classical geometry: may refer to solid geometry or classical Euclidean geometry. See geometry
words.name: Classical geometry

words.def: Classical invariant theory: the form of invariant theory that deals with describing polynomial functions that are invariant under transformations from a given linear group.
words.name: Classical invariant theory

words.def: Classical mathematics: the standard approach to mathematics based on classical logic and ZFC set theory.
words.name: Classical mathematics

words.def: Clifford analysis: the study of Dirac operators and Dirac type operators from geometry and analysis using clifford algebras.
words.name: Clifford analysis

words.def: Clifford theory is a branch of representation theory spawned from Cliffords theorem.
words.name: Clifford theory

words.def: Combinatorial commutative algebra: a discipline viewed as the intersection between commutative algebra and combinatorics. It frequently employs methods from one to address problems arising in the other. Polyhedral geometry also plays a significant role.
words.name: Combinatorial commutative algebra

words.def: Combinatorial design theory: a part of combinatorial mathematics that deals with the existence and construction of systems of fintie sets whose intersections have certain properties.
words.name: Combinatorial design theory

words.def: Combinatorial geometry: see discrete geometry
words.name: Combinatorial geometry

words.def: Combinatorial group theory: the theory of free groups and the presentation of a group. It is closely related to geometric group theory and is applied in geometric topology.
words.name: Combinatorial group theory

words.def: Combinatorial set theory: also known as Infinitary combinatorics. see infinitary combinatorics
words.name: Combinatorial set theory

words.def: Combinatorial topology: an old name for algebraic topology, when topological invariants of spaces were regarded as derived from combinatorial decompositions.
words.name: Combinatorial topology

words.def: Combinatorics: a branch of discrete mathematics concerned with countable structures. Branches of it include enumerative combinatorics, combinatorial design theory, matroid theory, extremal combinatorics and algebraic combinatorics, as well as many more.
words.name: Combinatorics

words.def: Commutative algebra: a branch of abstract algebra studying commutative rings.
words.name: Commutative algebra

words.def: Complex algebraic geometry: the mainstream of algebraic geometry devoted to the study of the complex points of algebraic varieties.
words.name: Complex algebraic geometry

words.def: Complex analysis: a part of analysis that deals with functions of a complex variable.
words.name: Complex analysis

words.def: Complex analytic dynamics: a subdivision of complex dynamics being the study of the dynamic systems defined by analytic functions.
words.name: Complex analytic dynamics

words.def: Complex analytic geometry: the application of complex numbers to plane geometry.
words.name: Complex analytic geometry

words.def: Complex differential geometry: a branch of differential geometry that studies complex manifolds.
words.name: Complex differential geometry

words.def: Complex dynamics: the study of dynamical systems defined by iterated functions on complex number spaces.
words.name: Complex dynamics

words.def: Complex geometry: the study of complex manifolds and functions of complex variables. It includes complex algebraic geometry and complex analytic geometry.
words.name: Complex geometry

words.def: Complexity theory: the study of complex systems with the inclusion of the theory of complex systems.
words.name: Complexity theory

words.def: Computable analysis: the study of which parts of real analysis and functional analysis can be carried out in a computable manner. It is closely related to constructive analysis.
words.name: Computable analysis

words.def: Computable model theory: a branch of model theory dealing with the relevant questions computability.
words.name: Computable model theory

words.def: Computability theory: a branch of mathematical logic originating in the 1930s with the study of computable functions and Turing degrees, but now includes the study of generalized computability and definability. It overlaps with proof theory and effective descriptive set theory.
words.name: Computability theory

words.def: Computational complexity theory: a branch of mathematics and theoretical computer science that focuses on classifying computational problems according to their inherent difficulty, and relating those classes to each other.
words.name: Computational complexity theory

words.def: Computational group theory: the study of groups by means of computers.
words.name: Computational group theory

words.def: Computational mathematics: the mathematical research in areas of science where computing plays an essential role.
words.name: Computational mathematics

words.def: Computational number theory: also known as algorithmic number theory, it is the study of algorithms for performing number theoretic computations.
words.name: Computational number theory

words.def: Computer algebra: see symbolic computation
words.name: Computer algebra

words.def: Conformal geometry: the study of conformal transformations on a space.
words.name: Conformal geometry

words.def: Constructive analysis: mathematical analysis done according to the principles of constructive mathematics. This differs from classical analysis.
words.name: Constructive analysis

words.def: Constructive function theory: a branch of analysis that is closely related to approximation theory, studying the connection between the smoothness of a function and its degree of approximation
words.name: Constructive function theory

words.def: Constructive mathematics: mathematics which tends to use intuitionistic logic. Essentially that is classical logic but without the assumption that the law of the excluded middle is an axiom.
words.name: Constructive mathematics

words.def: Constructive quantum field theory: a branch of mathematical physics that is devoted to showing that quantum theory is mathematically compatible with special relativity.
words.name: Constructive quantum field theory

words.def: Contact geometry: a branch of differential geometry and topology, closely related to and considered the odd-dimensional counterpart of symplectic geometry. It is the study of a geometric structure called a contact structure on a differentiable manifold.
words.name: Contact geometry

words.def: Convex analysis: the study of properties of convex functions and convex sets.
words.name: Convex analysis

words.def: Convex geometry: part of geometry devoted to the study of convex sets.
words.name: Convex geometry

words.def: Coordinate geometry: see analytic geometry
words.name: Coordinate geometry

words.def: CR geometry: a branch of differential geometry, being the study of CR manifolds.
words.name: CR geometry

words.def: Descriptive set theory: a part of mathematical logic, more specifically a part of set theory dedicated to the study of Polish spaces.
words.name: Descriptive set theory

words.def: Differential algebraic geometry: the adaption of methods and concepts from algebraic geometry to systems of algebraic differential equations.
words.name: Differential algebraic geometry

words.def: Differential calculus: a subfield of calculus concerned with derivatives or the rates that quantities change. It is one of two traditional divisions of calculus, the other being integral calculus.
words.name: Differential calculus

words.def: Differential Galois theory: the study of the Galois groups of differential fields.
words.name: Differential Galois theory

words.def: Differential geometry: a form of geometry that uses techniques from integral and differential calculus as well as linear and multilinear algebra to study problems in geometry. Classically, these were problems of Euclidean geometry, although now it has been expanded. It is generally concerned with geometric structures on differentiable manifolds. It is closely related to differential topology.
words.name: Differential geometry

words.def: Differential geometry of curves: the study of smooth curves in Euclidean space by using techniques from differential geometry
words.name: Differential geometry of curves

words.def: Differential geometry of surfaces: the study of smooth surfaces with various additional structures using the techniques of differential geometry.
words.name: Differential geometry of surfaces

words.def: Differential topology: a branch of topology that deals with differentiable functions on differentiable manifolds.
words.name: Differential topology

words.def: Diophantine geometry: in general the study of algebraic varieties over fields that are finitely generated over their prime fields.
words.name: Diophantine geometry

words.def: Discrete Morse theory: a combinatorial adaption of Morse theory.
words.name: Discrete Morse theory

words.def: Donaldson theory: the study of smooth 4-manifolds using gauge theory.
words.name: Donaldson theory

words.def: Econometrics: the application of mathematical and statistical methods to economic data.
words.name: Econometrics

words.def: Effective descriptive set theory: a branch of descriptive set theory dealing with set of real numbers that have lightface definitions. It uses aspects of computability theory.
words.name: Effective descriptive set theory

words.def: Elementary algebra: a fundamental form of algebra extending on elementary arithmetic to include the concept of variables.
words.name: Elementary algebra

words.def: Elementary arithmetic: the simplified portion of arithmetic considered necessary for primary education. It includes the usage addition, subtraction, multiplication and division of the natural numbers. It also includes the concept of fractions and negative numbers.
words.name: Elementary arithmetic

words.def: Elementary mathematics: parts of mathematics frequently taught at the primary and secondary school levels. This includes elementary arithmetic, geometry, probability and statistics, elementary algebra and trigonometry. (calculus is not usually considered a part)
words.name: Elementary mathematics

words.def: Elementary group theory: the study of the basics of group theory
words.name: Elementary group theory

words.def: Elimination theory: the classical name for algorithmic approaches to eliminating between polynomials of several variables. It is a part of commutative algebra and algebraic geometry.
words.name: Elimination theory

words.def: Elliptic geometry: a type of non-Euclidean geometry (it violates Euclid's parallel postulate) and is based on spherical geometry. It is constructed in elliptic space.
words.name: Elliptic geometry

words.def: Enumerative combinatorics: an area of combinatorics that deals with the number of ways that certain patterns can be formed.
words.name: Enumerative combinatorics

words.def: Enumerative geometry: a branch of algebraic geometry concerned with counting the number of solutions to geometric questions. This is usually done by means of intersection theory.
words.name: Enumerative geometry

words.def: Ergodic Ramsey theory: a branch where problems are motivated by additive combinatorics and solved using ergodic theory.
words.name: Ergodic Ramsey theory

words.def: Ergodic theory: the study of dynamical systems with an invariant measure, and related problems.
words.name: Ergodic theory

words.def: Euclidean differential geometry: also known as classical differential geometry. See differential geometry.
words.name: Euclidean differential geometry

words.def: Extremal combinatorics: a branch of combinatorics, it is the study of the possible sizes of a collection of finite objects given certain restrictions.
words.name: Extremal combinatorics

words.def: Field theory: branch of abstract algebra studying fields.
words.name: Field theory

words.def: Finsler geometry: a branch of differential geometry whose main object of study is the Finsler manifold (a generalisation of a Riemannian manifold).
words.name: Finsler geometry

words.def: Fractional calculus: a branch of analysis that studies the possibility of taking real or complex powers of the differentiation operator.
words.name: Fractional calculus

words.def: Fractional dynamics: investigates the behaviour of objects and systems that are described by differentiation and integration of fractional orders using methods of fractional calculus.
words.name: Fractional dynamics

words.def: Fredholm theory: part of spectral theory studying integral equations.
words.name: Fredholm theory

words.def: Function theory: part of analysis devoted to properties of functions, especially functions of a complex variable (see complex analysis).
words.name: Function theory

words.def: Functional calculus: historically the term was used synonymously with calculus of variations, but now refers to a branch of functional analysis connected with spectral theory
words.name: Functional calculus

words.def: Fuzzy mathematics: a branch of mathematics based on fuzzy set theory and fuzzy logic.
words.name: Fuzzy mathematics

words.def: Fuzzy set theory: a form of set theory that studies fuzzy sets, that is sets that have degrees of membership.
words.name: Fuzzy set theory

words.def: Galois cohomology: an application of homological algebra, it is the study of group cohomology of Galois modules.
words.name: Galois cohomology

words.def: Galois theory: named after Évariste Galois, it is a branch of abstract algebra providing a connection between field theory and group theory.
words.name: Galois theory

words.def: Galois geometry: a branch of finite geometry concerned with algebraic and analytic geometry over a Galois field.
words.name: Galois geometry

words.def: General topology: also known as point-set topology, it is a branch of topology studying the properties of topological spaces and structures defined on them. It differs from other branches of topology as the topological spaces do not have to be similar to manifolds.
words.name: General topology

words.def: Generalized trigonometry: developments of trigonometric methods from the application to real numbers of Euclidean geometry to any geometry or space. This includes spherical trigonometry, hyperbolic trigonometry, gyrotrigonometry, rational trigonometry, universal hyperbolic trigonometry, fuzzy qualitative trigonometry, operator trigonometry and lattice trigonometry.
words.name: Generalized trigonometry

words.def: Geometric algebra: an alternative approach to classical, computational and relativistic geometry. It shows a natural correspondence between geometric entities and elements of algebra.
words.name: Geometric algebra

words.def: Geometric analysis: a discipline that uses methods from differential geometry to study partial differential equations as well as the applications to geometry.
words.name: Geometric analysis

words.def: Geometric function theory: the study of geometric properties of analytic functions.
words.name: Geometric function theory

words.def: Geometric topology: a branch of topology studying manifolds and mappings between them; in particular the embedding of one manifold into another.
words.name: Geometric topology

words.def: Geometry: a branch of mathematics concerned with shape and the properties of space. Classically it arose as what is now known as solid geometry; this was concerning practical knowledge of length, area and volume. It was then put into an axiomatic form by Euclid, giving rise to what is now known as classical Euclidean geometry. The use of coordinates by René Descartes gave rise to Cartesian geometry enabling a more analytical approach to geometric entities. Since then many other branches have appeared including projective geometry, differential geometry, non-Euclidean geometry, Fractal geometry and algebraic geometry. Geometry also gave rise to the modern discipline of topology.
words.name: Geometry

words.def: Geometry of numbers: initiated by Hermann Minkowski, it is a branch of number theory studying convex bodies and integer vectors.
words.name: Geometry of numbers

words.def: Global analysis: the study of differential equations on manifolds and the relationship between differential equations and topology.
words.name: Global analysis

words.def: Graph theory: a branch of discrete mathematics devoted to the study of graphs. It has many applications in physical, biological and social systems.
words.name: Graph theory

words.def: Group-character theory: the part of character theory dedicated to the study of characters of group representations.
words.name: Group-character theory

words.def: Gyrotrigonometry: a form of trigonometry used in gyrovector space for hyperbolic geometry. (An analogy of the vector space in Euclidean geometry.)
words.name: Gyrotrigonometry

words.def: Hard analysis: see classical analysis
words.name: Hard analysis

words.def: Harmonic analysis: part of analysis concerned with the representations of functions in terms of waves. It generalizes the notions of Fourier series and Fourier transforms from the Fourier analysis.
words.name: Harmonic analysis

words.def: Holomorphic functional calculus: a branch of functional calculus starting with holomorphic functions.
words.name: Holomorphic functional calculus

words.def: Homological algebra: the study of homology in general algebraic settings.
words.name: Homological algebra

words.def: Hyperbolic geometry: also known as Lobachevskian geometry or Bolyai-Lobachevskian geometry. It is a non-Euclidean geometry looking at hyperbolic space.
words.name: Hyperbolic geometry

words.def: hyperbolic trigonometry: the study of hyperbolic triangles in hyperbolic geometry, or hyperbolic functions in Euclidean geometry. Other forms include gyrotrigonometry and universal hyperbolic trigonometry.
words.name: hyperbolic trigonometry

words.def: Ideal theory: once the precursor name for what is now known as commutative algebra; it is the theory of ideals in commutative rings.
words.name: Ideal theory

words.def: Incidence geometry: the study of relations of incidence between various geometric objects, like curves and lines.
words.name: Incidence geometry

words.def: Inconsistent mathematics: see paraconsistent mathematics.
words.name: Inconsistent mathematics

words.def: Infinitary combinatorics: an expansion of ideas in combinatorics to account for infinite sets.
words.name: Infinitary combinatorics

words.def: Infinitesimal analysis: once a synonym for infinitesimal calculus
words.name: Infinitesimal analysis

words.def: Infinitesimal calculus: see calculus of infinitesimals
words.name: Infinitesimal calculus

words.def: Intersection theory: a branch of algebraic geometry and algebraic topology
words.name: Intersection theory

words.def: Invariant theory: studies how group actions on algebraic varieties affect functions.
words.name: Invariant theory

words.def: Inversive geometry: the study of invariants preserved by a type of transformation known as inversion
words.name: Inversive geometry

words.def: Inversive plane geometry: inversive geometry that is limited to two dimensions
words.name: Inversive plane geometry

words.def: K-theory: originated as the study of a ring generated by vector bundles over a topological space or scheme. In algebraic topology it is an extraordinary cohomology theory known as topological K-theory. In algebra and algebraic geometry it is referred to as algebraic K-theory. In physics, K-theory has appeared in type II string theory. (In particular twisted K-theory.)
words.name: K-theory

words.def: Kähler geometry: a branch of differential geometry, more specifically a union of Riemannian geometry, complex differential geometry and symplectic geometry. It is the study of Kähler manifolds. (named after Erich Kähler)
words.name: Kähler geometry

words.def: Knot theory: part of topology dealing with knots
words.name: Knot theory

words.def: Large deviations theory: part of probability theory studying events of small probability (tail events).
words.name: Large deviations theory

words.def: Large sample theory: also known as asymptotic theory
words.name: Large sample theory

words.def: Lattice theory: the study of lattices, being important in order theory and universal algebra
words.name: Lattice theory

words.def: Linear algebra – a branch of algebra studying linear spaces and linear maps. It has applications in fields such as abstract algebra and functional analysis; it can be represented in analytic geometry and it is generalized in operator theory and in module theory. Sometimes matrix theory is considered a branch, although linear algebra is restricted to only finite dimensions. Extensions of the methods used belong to multilinear algebra.
words.name: Linear algebra

words.def: Local algebra: a term sometimes applied to the theory of local rings.
words.name: Local algebra

words.def: Local arithmetic dynamics: also known as p-adic dynamics or nonarchimedean dynamics.
words.name: Local arithmetic dynamics

words.def: Mathematical physics: a part of mathematics that develops mathematical methods motivated by problems in physics.
words.name: Mathematical physics

words.def: Mathematical sciences: refers to academic disciplines that are mathematical in nature, but are not considered proper subfields of mathematics. Examples include statistics, cryptography, game theory and actuarial science.
words.name: Mathematical sciences

words.def: Modern algebra: see abstract algebra
words.name: Modern algebra

words.def: Modern algebraic geometry: the form of algebraic geometry given by Alexander Grothendieck and Jean-Pierre Serre drawing on sheaf theory.
words.name: Modern algebraic geometry

words.def: Modern invariant theory: the form of invariant theory that analyses the decomposition of representations into irreducibles.
words.name: Modern invariant theory

words.def: Morse theory: a part of differential topology, it analyzes the topological space of a manifold by studying differentiable functions on that manifold.
words.name: Morse theory

words.def: Multilinear algebra: an extension of linear algebra building upon concepts of p-vectors and multivectors with Grassmann algebra.
words.name: Multilinear algebra

words.def: Multiplicative number theory: a subfield of analytic number theory that deals with prime numbers, factorization and divisors.
words.name: Multiplicative number theory

words.def: Neutral geometry: see absolute geometry
words.name: Neutral geometry

words.def: Nevanlinna theory: part of complex analysis studying the value distribution of meromorphic functions. It is named after Rolf Nevanlinna
words.name: Nevanlinna theory

words.def: Nielsen theory: an area of mathematical research with its origins in fixed point topology, developed by Jakob Nielsen
words.name: Nielsen theory

words.def: Nonarchimedean dynamics: also known as p-adic analysis or local arithmetic dynamics
words.name: Nonarchimedean dynamics

words.def: Noncommutative algebraic geometry: a direction in noncommutative geometry studying the geometric properties of formal duals of non-commutative algebraic objects.
words.name: Noncommutative algebraic geometry

words.def: Noncommutative harmonic analysis: see representation theory
words.name: Noncommutative harmonic analysis

words.def: Number theory: a branch of pure mathematics primarily devoted to the study of the integers. Originally it was known as arithmetic or higher arithmetic.
words.name: Number theory

words.def: Operad theory: a type of abstract algebra concerned with prototypical algebras.
words.name: Operad theory

words.def: Operator theory: part of functional analysis studying operators.
words.name: Operator theory

words.def: Optimal control theory: a generalization of the calculus of variations.
words.name: Optimal control theory

words.def: Order theory: a branch that investigates the intuitive notion of order using binary relations.
words.name: Order theory

words.def: Ordered geometry: a form of geometry omitting the notion of measurement but featuring the concept of intermediacy. It is a fundamental geometry forming a common framework for affine geometry, Euclidean geometry, absolute geometry and hyperbolic geometry.
words.name: Ordered geometry

words.def: p-adic analysis: a branch of number theory that deals with the analysis of functions of p-adic numbers.
words.name: p-adic analysis

words.def: p-adic dynamics: an application of p-adic analysis looking at p-adic differential equations.
words.name: p-adic dynamics

words.def: Paraconsistent mathematics: sometimes called inconsistent mathematics, it is an attempt to develop the classical infrastructure of mathematics based on a foundation of paraconsistent logic instead of classical logic.
words.name: Paraconsistent mathematics

words.def: Point-set topology: see general topology
words.name: Point-set topology

words.def: Polyhedral combinatorics: a branch within combinatorics and discrete geometry that studies the problems of describing convex polytopes.
words.name: Polyhedral combinatorics

words.def: Projective geometry: a form of geometry that studies geometric properties that are invariant under a projective transformation.
words.name: Projective geometry

words.def: Pseudo-Riemannian geometry: generalizes Riemannian geometry to the study of pseudo-Riemannian manifolds.
words.name: Pseudo-Riemannian geometry

words.def: Pure mathematics: the part of mathematics that studies entirely abstract concepts.
words.name: Pure mathematics

words.def: Quantum calculus: a form of calculus without the notion of limits. There are 2 forms known as q-calculus and h-calculus
words.name: Quantum calculus

words.def: Quantum geometry: the generalization of concepts of geometry used to describe the physical phenomena of quantum physics
words.name: Quantum geometry

words.def: Ramsey theory: the study of the conditions in which order must appear. It is named after Frank P. Ramsey.
words.name: Ramsey theory

words.def: Rational trigonometry: a reformulation of trigonometry in terms of spread and quadrance instead of angle and length.
words.name: Rational trigonometry

words.def: Real algebra: the study of the part of algebra relevant to real algebraic geometry.
words.name: Real algebra

words.def: Real algebraic geometry: the part of algebraic geometry that studies real points of the algebraic varieties.
words.name: Real algebraic geometry

words.def: Real analysis: a branch of mathematical analysis; in particular hard analysis, that is the study of real numbers and functions of Real values. It provides a rigorous formulation of the calculus of real numbers in terms of continuity and smoothness, whilst the theory is extended to the complex numbers in complex analysis.
words.name: Real analysis

words.def: Recreational mathematics: the area dedicated to mathematical puzzles and mathematical games.
words.name: Recreational mathematics

words.def: Recursion theory: see computability theory
words.name: Recursion theory

words.def: Representation theory: a subfield of abstract algebra; it studies algebraic structures by representing their elements as linear transformations of vector spaces. It also studies modules over these algebraic structures, providing a way of reducing problems in abstract algebra to problems in linear algebra.
words.name: Representation theory

words.def: Ribbon theory: a branch of topology studying ribbons.
words.name: Ribbon theory

words.def: Riemannian geometry: a branch of differential geometry that is more specifically, the study of Riemannian manifolds. It is named after Bernhard Riemann and it features many generalizations of concepts from Euclidean geometry, analysis and calculus.
words.name: Riemannian geometry

words.def: Rough set theory: the a form of set theory based on rough sets.
words.name: Rough set theory

words.def: Scheme theory: the study of schemes introduced by Alexander Grothendieck. It allows the use of sheaf theory to study algebraic varieties and is considered the central part of modern algebraic geometry.
words.name: Scheme theory

words.def: Semialgebraic geometry: a part of algebraic geometry; more specifically a branch of real algebraic geometry that studies semialgebraic sets.
words.name: Semialgebraic geometry

words.def: Single operator theory: deals with the properties and classifications of single operators.
words.name: Single operator theory

words.def: Singularity theory: a branch, notably of geometry; that studies the failure of manifold structure.
words.name: Singularity theory

words.def: Smooth infinitesimal analysis: a rigorous reformation of infinitesimal calculus employing methods of category theory. As a theory, it is a subset of synthetic differential geometry.
words.name: Smooth infinitesimal analysis

words.def: Spectral geometry: a field that concerns the relationships between geometric structures of manifolds and spectra of canonically defined differential operators.
words.name: Spectral geometry

words.def: Spectral graph theory: the study of properties of a graph using methods from matrix theory.
words.name: Spectral graph theory

words.def: Spectral theory: part of operator theory extending the concepts of eigenvalues and eigenvectors from linear algebra and matrix theory.
words.name: Spectral theory

words.def: Spectral theory of ordinary differential equations: part of spectral theory concerned with the spectrum and eigenfunction expansion associated with linear ordinary differential equations.
words.name: Spectral theory of ordinary differential equations

words.def: Spectrum continuation analysis: generalizes the concept of a Fourier series to non-periodic functions.
words.name: Spectrum continuation analysis

words.def: Spherical geometry: a branch of non-Euclidean geometry, studying the 2-dimensional surface of a sphere.
words.name: Spherical geometry

words.def: Spherical trigonometry: a branch of spherical geometry that studies polygons on the surface of a sphere. Usually the polygons are triangles.
words.name: Spherical trigonometry

words.def: Statistics: although the term may refer to the more general study of statistics, the term is used in mathematics to refer to the mathematical study of statistics and related fields. This includes probability theory.
words.name: Statistics

words.def: Stochastic geometry: the study of random patterns of points
words.name: Stochastic geometry

words.def: Surgery theory: a part of geometric topology referring to methods used to produce one manifold from another (in a controlled way.)
words.name: Surgery theory

words.def: Symbolic computation: also known as algebraic computation and computer algebra. It refers to the techniques used to manipulate mathematical expressions and equations in symbolic form as opposed to manipulating them by the numerical quantities represented by them.
words.name: Symbolic computation

words.def: Symplectic geometry: a branch of differential geometry and topology whose main object of study is the symplectic manifold.
words.name: Symplectic geometry

words.def: Synthetic differential geometry: a reformulation of differential geometry in the language of topos theory and in the context of an intuitionistic logic.
words.name: Synthetic differential geometry

words.def: Synthetic geometry: also known as axiomatic geometry, it is a branch of geometry that uses axioms and logical arguments to draw conclusions as opposed to analytic and algebraic methods.
words.name: Synthetic geometry

words.def: Systolic geometry: a branch of differential geometry studying systolic invariants of manifolds and polyhedra.
words.name: Systolic geometry

words.def: Systolic hyperbolic geometry: the study of systoles in hyperbolic geometry.
words.name: Systolic hyperbolic geometry

words.def: Tensor analysis: the study of tensors, which play a role in subjects such as differential geometry, mathematical physics, algebraic topology, multilinear algebra, homological algebra and representation theory.
words.name: Tensor analysis

words.def: Tensor calculus: an older term for tensor analysis.
words.name: Tensor calculus

words.def: Tensor theory: an alternative name for tensor analysis.
words.name: Tensor theory

words.def: Theoretical physics: a branch primarily of the science physics that uses mathematical models and abstraction of physics to rationalize and predict phenomena.
words.name: Theoretical physics

words.def: Topological combinatorics: the application of methods from algebraic topology to solve problems in combinatorics.
words.name: Topological combinatorics

words.def: Transcendental number theory: a branch of number theory that revolves around the transcendental numbers.
words.name: Transcendental number theory

words.def: Trigonometry: the study of triangles and the relationships between the length of their sides, and the angles between them. It is essential to many parts of applied mathematics.
words.name: Trigonometry

words.def: Tropical analysis: see idempotent analysis
words.name: Tropical analysis

words.def: Twisted K-theory: a variation on K-theory, spanning abstract algebra, algebraic topology and operator theory.
words.name: Twisted K-theory

words.def: Umbral calculus: the study of Sheffer sequences
words.name: Umbral calculus

words.def: Uncertainty theory: a new branch of mathematics based on normality, monotonicity, self-duality, countable subadditivity, and product measure axioms.
words.name: Uncertainty theory

words.def: Universal algebra: a field studying the formalization of algebraic structures itself.
words.name: Universal algebra

words.def: Universal hyperbolic trigonometry: an approach to hyperbolic trigonometry based on rational geometry.
words.name: Universal hyperbolic trigonometry

words.def: Vector algebra: a part of linear algebra concerned with the operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication, although it may also refer to vector operations of vector calculus, including the dot and cross product. In this case it can be contrasted with geometric algebra which generalizes into higher dimensions.
words.name: Vector algebra

words.def: Vector analysis: also known as vector calculus, see vector calculus.
words.name: Vector analysis

words.def: Vector calculus: a branch of multivariable calculus concerned with differentiation and integration of vector fields. Primarily it is concerned with 3-dimensional Euclidean space.
words.name: Vector calculus
